Exercises 11 (Binomial expansion) Expand the following using the binomial expansion: \((a+2x)^5\) \(\left(3a-\dfrac{x}{2}\right)^3\) \(\left(\dfrac{x}{4}-a\right)^4\) If \(x\) is so small that terms in \(x^5\) and higher may be neglected, show that \[(x - 3)^2(1 + x)^9 \approx 666x^4 + 549x^3 + 271x^2 + 75x + 9.\] Expand the following to the fourth term using the binomial expansion: \((1+6x)^3\) \(\left(1-\dfrac{5x}{2}\right)^{-3}\) \(\dfrac{1}{(1+3x)^3}\) \(\sqrt{1-2x}\) Assuming that \(x\) is so small that terms in \(x^3\) and higher may be ignored, show that \[\frac{1-\frac{x}{2}}{\sqrt{1+\frac{x}{2}}}\approx 1-\frac{3x}{4}+\frac{7x^2}{32}.\] Assuming \(x\) is small, expand \(\dfrac{\sqrt{1-x}}{\sqrt{1+2x}}\) up to and including the term in \(x^2\). Using the binomial expansion, evaluate to three decimal places: \(\sqrt{1.01}\) \(\sqrt[3]{27.3}\) Using the binomial approximation, simplify: \(\dfrac{\sqrt{1+2x}}{(12+4x)^2}\) \(\dfrac{1}{(3x-2)(1+3x)^{-\frac12}}\) \(\dfrac{1-6x+9x^2}{\sqrt{1+6x}}\) Expand the following in: \((3 + x)^3\) \((5 + 2x)^3\) \((2 + x)^4\) \((2 - x)^4\) \((2y + x)^5\) \((2x - 3y)^5\) \(\left(x-\dfrac{1}{x}\right)^4\) \(\left(x-\dfrac{2}{x}\right)^5\) Expand \((2 + x)^5\) and use your expansion to find a) \((2.1)^5\) and b) \((1.9)^5\).
